abstract: Trading scandal may strengthen New York Stock Exchange; scandal bears close resemblence to one that shook Nasdaq stock market decade ago; in Nasdaq case, scandal forced market to clean house at top and to institute reforms that ended practices that had enabled brokers to systematically take advantage of their customers; result was far better market, one that was able to withstand intense public scrutiny that arrived few years later when technology stock boom cast light on Nasdaq; indictment of 15 former specialists could make this largest criminal case to come out of America's premier stock exchange since 1930's, when exchange's president, Richard Whitney, was imprisoned for fraud; photo (Market Place column) (M)

lead_paragraph: A scandal can destroy an institution. Or it can renew it. The good news for the New York Stock Exchange is that the scandal that led to the indictments of people who had been extremely powerful on the floor of the exchange bears a close resemblance to the one that shook the Nasdaq stock market a decade ago.

abstract: Attractions    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. Through Aug. 7, ''Exploring Bolivia's Biodiversity,'' an exhibition of more than 30 color photographs. Through May 30, ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' a walk-in display of hundreds of live specimens. Through the spring, ''Vital Variety: A Visual Celebration of Invertebrate Biodiversity,'' an exhibition of 24 large-format color photographs by the entomologist Piotr Naskrecki, in the gallery next to the Imax theater. Through July, ''Totems to Turquoise: Native North American Jewelry Arts of the Northwest,'' with more than 500 pieces of contemporary and historic jewelry. The Arthur Ross Hall of Meteorites displays the 34-ton Ahnighito meteorite, the world's largest. In the Imax theater, ''Vikings: Journey to New Worlds,'' and ''Jane Goodall's Wild Chimpanzees.'' Tickets to one Imax feature, including museum admission, are $19; students and 60+, $14; children under 12, $11. Timed tickets to the ''Butterfly Conservatory'' and general admission to ''Totems to Turquoise'' are $19; students and 60+ and for those 12 and younger, $14. Suggested general admission: $13; students and 60+, $10; 12 and younger, $7.50; under 2, free. Combination tickets are available, including museum and Rose Center admission and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $22; students and 60+, $16.50; 12 and younger, $13; under 2, free. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., except the first Friday of most months, when the Rose Center is open until 8:45 p.m. for ''Starry Nights.'' Information: amnh.org; (212)769-5100 or (212)769-5200.    HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th to 19th centuries, restored and furnished. Saturday night tavern shows at 7:30 and 9 p.m.; tomorrow, the group Point Cross.; tickets, $12. Museum admission: $5; 62+, $4; students and children 5 to 17, $3.50; children under 5 and members, free. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Information: (718)351-1611.    MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. This preserved late-Federal brick house with a Greek Revival interior, once owned by Seabury Tredwell, a wealthy hardware dealer, was built in 1832. Sunday at 5:30 p.m., ''Farewell Father, Friend and Guardian,'' a concert of songs written in 1865 to commemorate Abraham Lincoln's death, featuring members of the Bond Street European Singing Society, and a slide lecture. Fee, $15, members, $12. Self-guided tours are available on weekdays; guided tours on Saturdays and Sundays. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; students and 62+, $5 members and children under 12, free. Information: (212) 777-1089.    MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 36-01 35th Avenue, at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. Running through May 30, ''Digital Play: Reloaded,'' an interactive display of video and digital games including Pac-Mondrian, Pac Man, Donkey Kong and Stepmania. Through Sunday, a Marx Brothers series with ''The Cocoanuts'' (1929), directed by Joseph Santley (tomorrow at 2 p.m.); ''Duck Soup'' (1933), directed by Leo McCarey (tomorrow at 4 p.m.); ''Monkey Business'' (1931), directed by Norman Z. McLeod (Sunday at 2 p.m.); ''Horse Feathers'' (1932), directed by Mr. McLeod (Sunday at 4 p.m.). Also this weekend: ''Beyond the Sea'' (2003), a documentary by Lisandro Perez-Rey (tonight at 7:30) and ''Sans Soleil'' (1982) and ''La Jetée'' (1962) both directed by Chris Marker (tomorrow and Sunday night at 6:30). Museum hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, noon to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6:30 p.m.; and by appointment. Film and video showings are free with admission unless otherwise noted. Museum admission: $10; 65+ and students, $7.50; ages 5 to 18, $5; free for members and children 4 and younger and for everyone on Fridays from 4 to 8 p.m.; Friday-night screenings are extra. Information: www.movingimage.us or (718)784-0077.    Recreation    SECOND MORE MARATHON, Central Park. Broadway    'DIRTY ROTTEN SCOUNDRELS' Is there room on Broadway for another odd couple of singing con men? On paper, this tale of two mismatched scam artists has an awful lot in common with ''The Producers.'' But if you are going to court comparison with giants, you had better be prepared to stand tall. ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' directed by Jack O'Brien and starring John Lithgow and Nobert Leo Butz, never straightens out of a queasy slouch. Though shot through a rowdy spirit of self-parody, the show (with songs by David Yazbek) seems to believe in its own brazen agenda only when the criminally talented Mr. Butz commands the stage. RATLIFF    *SAXOPHONE SUMMIT: JOE LOVANO, MICHAEL BRECKER, DAVE LIEBMAN, Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. All wide-ranging players who have made a big impact on the way jazz saxophone has been played since John Coltrane, Mr. Lovano, Mr. Brecker and Mr. Liebman convene every once in a while on the same stage; they're an impressive crew. Sets tonight and tomorrow are at 9 and 11; cover charge is $40 and there is a $10 minimum at the tables. RATLIFF    *SF JAZZ COLLECTIVE, Rose Theater, Frederick P. Rose Hall, 60th Street at Broadway, (212)721-6500. An octet of jazz musicians all worthwhile in their own right, and it's the house band of SFJazz, the arts-producing organization that often seems like the West Coast version of Jazz at Lincoln Center. The band includes the saxophonists Joshua Redman and Miguel Zenon, the vibraphonist Bobby Hutcherson, the pianist Renee Rosnes, the trombonist Isaac Smith, the bassist Matt Penman and the drummer Eric Harland; they are touring with a program of originals by the various group members, commissioned by SFJazz, and also of re-worked Coltrane pieces, arranged by Gil Goldstein, the band's de facto (off-stage) ninth member. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; remaining tickets are $70 to $150. RATLIFF    TIM BERNE'S HARD CELL, 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 929-9883. A group with Tim Berne on saxophones, Craig Taborn on synthesizer and Tom Rainey on drums; they play chopped-off funk lines, gathering momentum into what are very nearly grooves, and extend them into long, highly improvised joyrides. Tonight at 10 pm; cover charge is $10. RATLIFF    *TRIBUTE TO JIMMY SMITH, WITH JOEY DEFRANCESCO TRIO, Iridium, 1650 Broadway at 51st Street, (212)582-2121. In the 1950's, Jimmy Smith developed a pathbreaking style on the Hammond organ: he used Charlie Parker as an improvisatory model and made it sound percussive. He influenced lots of players on the instrument, and Joey DeFrancesco is one of the younger beneficiaries of Mr. Smith's greatness; before Mr. Smith died last month, the two organists made an album together, ''Legacy,'' on Concord. Sets through Sunday night are at 8 and 10, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $30 and there is a $10 minimum. Opera    'CARMEN' City Opera offers a straightforward production of Bizet's familiar story about the gypsy and the soldier; it's left to the singers to offer insight. The cast for this season's revival includes two singers new to the company. John Bellemer, the Don José, has been singing in France and Germany, as well as American regional companies, and will returns this summer to the Opera Theater of St. Louis; Malcolm MacKenzie, the Escamillo, hails from California and is a veteran of the regional circuit. Most eyes and ears will of course focus on Carmen: Katharine Goeldner, a mezzo who has won praise in previous outings at City Opera. Gary Thor Wedow conducts. Tomorrow night at 8, New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212)870-5570. Tickets: $32 to $115. ANNE MIDGETTE    'CAVALLERIA RUSTICANA' AND 'PAGLIACCI' The Metropolitan Opera's run of the ''Cavalleria Rusticana''/''Pagliacci'' double bill winds down its season run with tomorrow's matinee. Santuzza and Turiddu in Mascagni's ''Cavalleria Rusticana'' are Violeta Urmana and Eduardo Villa. Nedda in Leoncavallo's ''Pagliacci'' is Patricia Racette, with John Mac Master and Juan Pons as Canio and Tonio. Dennis Russell Davies conducts. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000. Tickets: $75 to $315 . BERNARD HOLLAND    'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' The essentials of Puccini's opera are well-served in Mark Lamos's spare, attractive production, in which a magnified and uncluttered version of a traditional Japanese house fills the stage. The cast includes Gerard Powers as Pinkerton, Lori Phillips as Butterfly, John Packard as Sharpless and Jennifer Dawn Hines as Suzuki. Steven Mosteller conducts, and has the orchestra sounding quite good, if perhaps a bit too loud for the singers. Tonight at 8, Sunday at 1:30. New York State Theater. (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $27 to $105 tonight; $32 to $115 on Sunday. ALLAN KOZINN    *'ORLANDO' No Handel opera is musically richer and more psychologically resonant than ''Orlando.'' The story, adapted from Ariosto, tells of a renowned knight who, tired of pursuing glory though combat, turns his attention to love. But a magician, Zoroastro, intent on steering Orlando back to the path of valor, entices him into a forest where romantic entanglements drive him temporarily mad. The New York City Opera's imaginative new production by the director Chas Rader-Shieber is set in a wondrous storybook forest with marbled doorways serving as enchanted portals to the courtly world the forest travelers have left behind. The cast is first rate, with the exciting countertenor Bejun Mehta in the title role. The robust bass-baritone David Pittsinger sings Zoroastro. Antony Walker conducts. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212)870-5570. Tickets: $32 to $115. ANTHONYTOMMASINI    'DER ROSENKAVALIER' Strauss's much admired opera has returned to the Met with some familiar and fresh faces in the cast. Susan Graham is in fine form for her signature role as Octavian, and Laura Aikin sings Sophie with a pure and silken tone. The beguiling newcomer here is the German soprano Angela Denoke, who brings an affecting sense of vulnerability to the world-weary Marschallin. Her performance is subtle, with high notes and a certain wistfulness wafting gently into the house. In the pit, Donald Runnicles stirs up the Met Orchestra, as if to remind us that ''Rosenkavalier'' has its modern edges, too, but he is also not afraid to bask in the more nostalgic moments of this beautiful score. The Met is still getting mileage off of Nathaniel Merrill's popular production, over three decades old and counting. Tomorrow night at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000. Tickets: $40 to $315. JEREMYEICHLER    'TOSCA' The young Italian tenor Salvatore Licitra made a last-minute debut at the Metropolitan Opera in May of 2002, substituting for Luciano Pavarotti in Puccini's ''Tosca'' on what was assumed (incorrectly, it turned out) would be Mr. Pavarotti's farewell to the Met. On that night, Mr. Licitra, who was 33 at the time, seemed an immensely gifted tenor with an exciting but raw and unfinished voice. He is back at the Met for the first time since his dramatic debut, again as Cavaradossi in ''Tosca.'' Unfortunately, as an artist and singer he remains a work in progress. He still boasts a dusky-toned and powerful voice and sings with youthful energy and fervor. But he was vocally cautious on the first night of the Met's revival of Franco Zeffirelli's 1985 production and his phrasing was sometimes labored. His Tosca, the veteran soprano Maria Guleghina, as is her way, sacrifices beauty of sound and lyrical elegance for the sake of hard-edged power and dramatic intensity. The excellent baritone Mark Delavan makes a vocally robust and dramatically imposing Scarpia. James Conlon conducts. Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000. Remaining tickets: $200 to $315; returns, if available, are sold before the performance. TOMMASINI    Classical Music    AMERICAN FESTIVAL OF MICROTONAL MUSIC The principle that drives microtonality is that the Western scale need not be divided into only 12 notes -- it can just as usefully be divided into 20, 50, or any number a composer decides upon, so long as instruments can be made on which the pitches can be played, and as long as musicians are willing to learn them. There has long been a sufficiently large group of microtonal composers and performers in New York -- and listeners interested in what they are up to -- for the bassoonist and composer Johnny Reinhard to run an annual festival of the music. This year's Microfest includes three programs, the first of which includes some standard repertory (works by Telemann, Beethoven, Mendelssohn and Schumann) played on instruments in non-standard tunings, as well as new works by Mordecai Sandberg and Mr. Reinhard. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Faust and Harrison Pianos, 205 West 58th Street. (212) 517-3550. Tickets: $15, $10 for students and 65+. KOZINN    BROOKLYN PHILHARMONIC Ute Lemper has never sung at the Brooklyn Academy of Music; but this weekend, the unrelentingly striking German chanteuse will change that state of affairs by appearing in Kurt Weill's ''Seven Deadly Sins'' with the all-male a capella ensemble Hudson Shad. Since one appearance cannot be enough for Ms. Lemper, she will also perform a selection of French chansons. The accompanist -- and presenter -- is the Brooklyn Philharmonic, which is offering Hindemith's ''Kammermusik No. 1'' and Ravel's ''Tombeau de Couperin'' by way of contextualization of Ms. Lemper's offerings. Carl St. Clair, the conductor, will make his debut with the orchestra. Tomorrow night at 8, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, (718)636-4100. Tickets: $20 to $60. MIDGETTE    NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC Kent Nagano is visiting the New York Philharmonic this week, conducting a program of Bach and Messiaen. Excerpts from Bach's ''Art of Fugue'' arranged for orchestra is simply one more way to approach a work that is more a summation of Bach's thoughts on counterpoint than music for public performance. It may be as good a way to go as any. Sheryl Staples and Sherry Sylar will be the soloists in Bach's Violin and Oboe Concerto. After intermission, the young and very busy American conducts Messiaen's ''Éclairs sur l'Au-Delà.'' This afternoon at 2, tomorrow at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212)721-6500. Tickets: $22 to $74 today, $25 to $90 tomorrow night. HOLLAND    GARRICK OHLSSON This formidable pianist is, among other things, a veteran Beethovian, and this weekend he marshals his considerable expertise for an all-Beethoven recital featuring the Sonatas Nos. 4, 5, 21 and 27. The performance is presented by Peoples' Symphony Concerts, which means the ticket prices are amazingly low. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place, (212)586-4680. Tickets: $9, on sale in the high school lobby tomorrow at 6 p.m. EICHLER    POMERIUM This most venerable of New York's early-music vocal ensembles, founded in 1972 and led by Alexander Blachly, consistently presents programs that offer both beautiful singing and scholarly enlightenment. Its program at the Cloisters tomorrow is appropriately seasonal and includes chant for Easter, elaborations on chant melodies by Dufay and other composers and motets by Lassus, Monteverdi, Gesualdo and Byrd. Tomorrow at 1 and 3. The Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park, (212) 650-2290. Tickets: $35. Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance.    *JEROME BEL A French choreographer known for playful and sometimes irreverent productions offers the New York premiere of ''The Show Must Go On,'' a 90-minute piece that has been danced around the world. Its cast includes Mr. Bel's sisters and friends. Much of the work is antic, but there are also quiet moments of nostalgia to make audiences sigh as well as smile. Tonight and tomorrow at 7:30, Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212), 924-0077. Tickets: $20. JACK ANDERSON    'I LOVE TANGO' This is the last weekend to see this ''tango musical,'' which boasts four dancers and live string, bandoneon, piano and vocal music. Tonight and tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 4 p.m., Thalia Spanish Theater, 41-17 Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens, (718)729-3880. Tickets: $30; $27 for students and 65+. JENNIFER DUNNING    JETTE PERFORMANCE COMPANY This jazz performance company fuses classical jazz, musical theater, and commercial jazz-funk in dances by the company director Jay T. Jenkins, whose credits include the choreography for music videos and tours by rock artists like Prince and Cyndi Lauper. Tonight through Sunday at 8 p.m., Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212)334-7479. Tickets: $20; $25, tonight, with reception. DUNNING    *'UR POCALYPSE!' More sad news from the arts scene in Williamsburg. Karinne Keithley and Chris Yon are closing Ur, a ''neighborhood dance palace,'' as they put it, that doubled as a lively storefront studio and theater. But they're going out with a bang, in a program of dances by Mr. Yon created in collaboration with Ms. Keithley, Taryn Griggs, Andrew Dinwiddie and Sara Smith, set to new music by Justin Jones, Ms. Keithley and Chris Lauterbach. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Ur, 445 Grand Street, Brooklyn, (347) 546-5079. Suggested donation: $10. DUNNING    WORK AND SHOW FESTIVAL The TriBeCa Performing Arts Center showcases the dances created by its resident dance, theater and music artists for the year in this series. The dance component includes choreography by Kraig Patterson and Christina Suarez (tonight); Ellis Wood and Richard Rivera (tomorrow) and a marathon program of work by all the residents (next Sunday). Tonight and tomorrow at 7 p.m., TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, 199 Chambers Street, (212)220-1460. Tickets: $10 (dance and marathon events); $8 for students and 65+. Full reviews of recent shows: nytimes.com/art.    Museums    *'DIANE ARBUS REVELATIONS,' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212)535-7710, through May 30. Arbus could be cruel, but tenderness and melancholy were her finest modes of expression, the emotions that reveal themselves after her best pictures leave their first impression, which is often alarm. She captured a moment, the anxious 1950's and 60's, and -- this probably applies as much to Arbus as to any other photographer of the second half of the last century -- she captured New York. Appropriately, she is given the royal treatment at the Met, including some maddeningly dark, dense and absurdly theatrical galleries, like chapels, of memorabilia. That said, it touches her favorite subjects with grace. Even the shocking photographs of retarded women are sympathetic, implying that the world is full of wondrous things, if our eyes are open enough to recognize them, and that in the end we are all drawn together by our different flaws. Hours: Sundays, Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $15; students, $7 and 65+, $10. MICHAEL KIMMELMAN    'BASQUIAT,' Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718)683-5000, through June 5. In the 1980's, the hypertalented Jean-Michel Basquiat (1960-1988) wrote, painted and drew his way to fame, usually on the same surface. His loquacious, ugly-elegant ''letters to the world'' (Emily Dickinson's phrase) were in step with the 80's interest in collage and in redirecting the avant-garde strategies of Post-Minimalism into painting. But Basquiat also had an urgent subject: blackness, whose glories, histories and pain his art elucidates with extraordinary complexity, in volatile mixtures of ideas, emotions, colors and images that expand the viewer's experience of time and space. This generous retrospective has a few glitches -- too many works borrowed from too few collections and a slightly too empty look in some galleries -- but nothing really detracts from its power. Hours: Wednesdays to Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of every month). Admission: $8; students and 65+, $4. ROBERTA SMITH    *THOMAS DEMAND, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212)708-9400, through May 30. A generally stellar midcareer survey of the 40-year-old German artist, who makes life-size reconstructions of scenes, often ones he has come across in photographs, so as to take his own cinematic photographs. He is really a sculptor, making models of places to produce pictures that have the presence of paintings. His subject is more than just photography's inherent unreliability, its slipperiness as truth. It also entails memory. He has reconstructed, from photographs, the blown-up room where plotters failed to kill Hitler, and the studio of an artist whom Baader-Meinhof terrorists assaulted during the 1970's in order to blow up the house of a prosecutor who lived next door. Hours: Saturdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m.; closed Tuesdays. Admission: $20; $16 for 65+; $12 for students; children 16 and under and accompanied by an adult, free. Free on Fridays from 4 to 8 p.m. KIMMELMAN    'GREATER NEW YORK 2005,' P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718)784-2084, through Sept. 26. A youth-besotted, cheerful, immodestly ingratiating, finally disappointing jumbo survey of contemporary art, perusing a scene whose wide stylistic range, stress on drawing, persistent teenage infatuations and overall dexterousness are firmly entrenched characteristics of the marketplace. ''Greater New York'' gladly services this giddy scene -- with its abundant gifts but, on the whole, its short-lived prospects. The show is a mirror of the current power structure, in which earnest and cunning students, not even yet graduated, are emerging already branded with signature styles. There's something rather depressing about such youthful professionalism, even while it is undeniably impressive.There are various trendlets: Henry Darger meets the Little Prince. Dystopian nature. Gaudy America. On the whole, the show, like the burbling young art world, seems almost too able to please. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 62+. KIMMELMAN    *TIM HAWKINSON, Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street, (212)570-3676, through May 29. On the gee-whiz meter, Tim Hawkinson skews high. His midcareer retrospective, like a mad scientists' fair of screwball contraptions, hopscotches from one dexterous tour de force to the next. Each requires some head-scratching decipherment, inviting admiration for its doggedness, while not straining too hard to earn a viewer's love. Feats of physical fancy, when so dizzily executed, can be their own justification. Mr. Hawkinson's larger purpose, you might say, is simply wonderment. At the same time the art borrows a healthy strain of ludicrous wit from Samuel Beckett, who knew a thing or two about how to clown around smartly. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Friday 1 to 9 p.m.; closed Mondays and Tuesdays. Admission: $12; students and 62+, $9.50; children 12 and under, free. KIMMELMAN    'RENAISSANCE AND BAROQUE BRONZES FROM THE FITZWILLIAM MUSEUM, CAMBRIDGE,' the Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212)288-0700, through April 24. The third show recently mounted by the Frick devoted to small bronze sculptures, this one continues to enhance the notion that mini-bronzes can be as rewarding to the viewer as large-scale sculpture. The Fitzwilliam's elevation to world-class status in its holdings was helped materially by the donation, in 1995, of the superb collection built by Lt. Col. Mildmay Thomas Boscawen, an Englishman who ran sisal plantations in Africa. One of his prizes, shown here, is the finely wrought figure of an athlete doing a handstand, by the 16th-century French sculptor Barthelemy Prieur. Another splendid work given by a different donor is a pair of figure groups dating from 1717 by Massimiliano Soldani Benzi that derive from the classical myths of Jupiter's loves: ''Leda and the Swan With Cupid,'' and ''Ganymede and the Eagle With Cupid and a Dog.'' Though small, they have the charge of life-size works. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $15; students, $5; and 65+, $8. GRACE GLUECK    *'PETER PAUL RUBENS (1577-1640): THE DRAWINGS,' the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212)535-7710, through April 3. The show is sublime. It makes not the slightest difference that it has no grand thesis, provides no narrative arc, offers up a few newly discovered drawings and fresh, solid scholarship but no radical twist on the artist. If there is any artistic justice, the exhibition ought to inspire the sort of mobbish devotion that the Met show of Leonardo's drawings did two years ago. Reviewing the work seems a bit silly. What is there to say, except that the drawings illustrate the limits of what is humanly possible with a piece of chalk and a pen and paper? It is profoundly heartening. Rubens loved to draw and loved that he could draw like a god, and his joy is ours, in looking at what he drew. This includes a few drawings by other artists with which Rubens fussed, sticking in angels here, touching up a beard there. Rubens regarded drawings, other people's and his own, as organic, to be learned from and endlessly improved upon, like life. Hours and admission: See above. KIMMELMAN    Galleries: Uptown    NINA MUSHINSKY, Janos Gat, 1100 Madison Avenue, between 82nd and 83rd Streets, (212)327-0441, through April 2. Ms. Mushinsky is a New York-based painter who makes labor-intensive, all black-and-white pictures based on photographs she has taken in Central Europe. Her paintings of subjects like an antique dress in a history museum, a bleak highway ramp or blurry laughing people in a leafy backyard can take as long as two years to complete. They have a smudgy, dreamlike hyperreality. KEN JOHNSON    Galleries: 57th Street    JOSÉ DAMASCENO: 'BEYOND CIRCUMSTANCE,' the Project, 37 West 57th Street, (212)688-4673, through April 2. To describe too fully the single work in this Rio de Janeiro-based conceptualist's exhibition would rob viewers of its mild surprise factor. Suffice it to say that it squeezes surrealistic proliferation into an otherwise ordinary situation; that it toys adroitly with the architecture of the gallery; and that its strictly black-and-white palette is très chic. JOHNSON    LAWRENCE WEINER: 'EN ROUTE,' Marian Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212)977-7160, through April 2. A founding guru of Conceptual Art, Mr. Weiner was one of the first American artists to ditch the fusty view of art as material object. He stopped painting in 1968 and took to a notebook, where he ''dematerialized'' the visual by making an object of language itself, trying thus to dispense with expensive materials and the status-y collector competition that has driven art prices into the stratosphere. In this show, he is up to his usual tricks: making cryptic statements in diagrammatic wall texts and schematic drawings. His graphic ingenuity is coupled with words that sometimes add up to concrete poetry; one could think of him as a quirky poet-designer with a moral imperative. To paraphrase Gertrude Stein, there is a there there, but parsing it will get you nowhere. GLUECK    Galleries: Chelsea    MARK COHEN: 'GRIM STREET,' Bruce Silverstein, 535 West 24th Street, (212) 627-3930, through April 2. Mr. Cohen's famous photographs of a girl blowing a gum bubble so big it eclipses her face, of the extraordinarily gangly girl with the ball and bat and of the impish boy smoking a cigarette while his laughing friends look on are included here along with a selection of other oblique, mysterious, funny and sad pictures of children at play, people in cars, animals, street scenes and other subjects from ordinary life shot in the 70's in black and white and color. JOHNSON    STUART ELSTER, Lucas Schoormans, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3159, through April 16. The subject of Mr. Elster's sleek paintings is the ordinary American copper penny. Computer-scanned and digitally manipulated, it becomes the inspiration for spacey, glowing and pulsating fields of mottled coppery or silvery paint in which the bust of Abraham Lincoln and other distorted and fragmentary features of the coin have a ghostly presence. JOHNSON    LARRY ZOX: 'FIVE DECADES,' Stephen Haller Gallery, 542 West 26th Street, (212)741-7777, through April 5. Larry Zox's distinctive, color-drenched hard-edge canvases that made a splash in the Color Field movement of the 1960's form the bulk of this mini-retrospective, which covers his work from the late 50's to now. The signature 60's work, revealing his association with the group that included Frank Stella and Kenneth Noland, was based on a tricky geometrical scheme involving the interplay of diamonds and diagonals, which he worked with many variations and impressive results. His technique has since become much freer, and in his most recent, more emotive work, color seems more important than structure. It's been a long stretch between New York shows for Mr. Zox, and his return is welcome. GLUECK  Other Galleries    JEFF DAVIS: 'MY DEEP DARK PAIN IS LOVE,' KS Art, 73 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212)219-9918, through April 16. Mr. Davis's nutty, finely made, neo-hippie colored pencil drawings and watercolors feature little bearded, long-haired, naked men who are equal parts Jesus and Charles Manson in all sorts of mysteriously ceremonial and often orgiastic configurations. The artist also presents a selection of comically monstrous wax candles cast from modified Halloween masks. JOHNSON    Last Chance    'JEAN-MICHEL BASQUIAT: IN WORDS ONLY,' Cheim & Read, 547 West 25th Street, (212)242-7727, closing tomorrow. This excellent show concentrates on the cornerstones of Basquiat's art: language and a blocky, concise handwriting that amounts to a personal, almost digital typeface. The only images here are words, names, lists and phrases, often appropriated from odd places, like the index of a book on jazz or the title of a painting by Ter Borch. One nine-sheet work is simply a rewriting of the prolonged table of contents of ''Moby-Dick,'' suggesting a kind of poem. SMITH    'BODY PROXY: AN EXHIBITION BY NORMA JEANE,' Swiss Institute, 495 Broadway, near Broome Street, (212) 925-2035, closing tomorrow. Norma Jeane is the fictive persona in whose name a group of anonymous people produce works of conceptual art. This show includes a motorcycle that starts up and roars increasingly louder as you approach; a 100-kilometer-long strand of hair on a spool made by knotting together hairs from one person's head; and a round, flesh-colored sofa said to be saturated with sexually provocative pheromones that will get into your clothes if you sit on it. JOHNSON    IMRE KINSZKI, Klotz/Sirmon, 511 West 25th Street, (212)741-4764, closing tomorrow. Born in Budapest in 1901, Kinszki was a well-connected Modernist photographer whose works could stand up with pictures by more famous Hungarian peers like André Kertesz, Brassai and Laszlo Moholy-Nagy. The tiny, velvety contact prints from the 20's and 30's in this show are formally exquisite and often emotionally poignant. They include a monumental close-up of chess pieces; studies of buildings and shadows; and a lovely picture of a sleeping baby. Kinszki never left Hungary, and he died in a concentration camp in 1945. JOHNSON    'STRANGER TOWN,' Dinter Fine Art, 547 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212)947-2818, closing tomorrow. There's not much doubt that the definition of art is a lot more porous than it used to be, but the wind really blows through the cracks in this exhibition of drawings, paintings, videos, books, comic books, installations and T-shirts organized by the young artist Taylor McKimens. The talent hails from adjacent spheres like commercial illustration, graphic animation, Japanese manga and skateboarding. Standouts include the polymath drawings of Tomoo Gokita and the animated videos of Saiman Chow. And when the work isn't top-notch, it usually leads to something that is the music of the indie genius Daniel Johnston, for example. SMITH
